title: Prevent Migraines and Headaches by Managing Stress
author: WebMD Editorial Contributors

content: Everyone experiences stress. Our bodies are designed to feel stress and react to it. It keeps us alert and ready to avoid danger. But, when stress persists, the body begins to break down and illnesses, like headaches and migraines , can occur. The key to coping with stress is identifying stressors in your life, learning ways to reduce stress, and managing stress.

sections.heading: What Is Stress?
content: Stress is your reaction to any change that requires you to adjust or respond. It's important to remember that you can control stress because stress comes from how you respond to stressful events.

sections.heading: What Causes Stress?
content: Stress can be caused by anything that requires you to adjust to a change in your environment. Your body reacts to these changes with physical, mental, and emotional responses. We all have our own ways of coping with change, so the causes of stress can be different for each person.

sections.heading: How Can I Cope With Stress?
content: Experts agree that coping is a process rather than an event. Thus, an individual may alternate between several of the above coping strategies in order to cope with a stressful event.
bullets: Have realistic expectations; accept that there are events you cannot control.
Ask others to help or assist you.
Express distressing emotions. Be assertive instead of aggressive. "Assert" your feelings, opinions, or beliefs instead of becoming angry, combative, or passive.
Challenge previously held beliefs that are no longer adaptive.
Directly attempt to change the source of stress.
Distance yourself from the source of stress.
Stop smoking or other bad habits.
Maintain a healthy sense of self-esteem.

sections.heading: When Should I Seek Help for Managing Stress?
content: You should seek help in dealing with your stress when you experience any of the following:
bullets: Inability to cope with demands of daily life
Obsessive preoccupation with food and fear of becoming obese with no relationship to actual body weight
Significant change in sleeping or eating habits
Suicidal thoughts or urges to hurt others

sections.heading: Where Do I Go to Get Help Managing Stress?
bullets: Your personal doctor: They can determine if your stress is due to an anxiety disorder , a medical condition, or both and can refer you to a mental health professional, if necessary.
If you think you might hurt yourself or others, call the Suicide and Crisis Lifeline at 988, or go to the nearest emergency room.
